content.text: Substrate choice significantly impacts your White's Tree Frog's health. While these frogs are primarily arboreal (tree-dwelling), proper substrate prevents injury from falls and aids humidity management. This guide covers safe substrate options and species-specific depth requirements for White's Tree Frogs.

content.heading: Safe Substrate Options for White's Tree Frogs

content.text:
Coconut Fiber (Coco Coir / Eco Earth)
The gold standard for White's Tree Frogs. Retains moisture without becoming waterlogged, typically safe if ingested, affordable, and works for both bioactive and simple setups. Comes in compressed bricks (soak before use) or loose bags.

Organic Topsoil (Bioactive Only)
Mix with coco fiber (60% soil, 40% coco) for bioactive substrates. Provides nutrients for live plants and cleanup crew. MUST be organic, pesticide-free, fertilizer-free. Avoid brands with perlite (white chunks = choking hazard).

Paper Towels (Bare Minimum Setup)
Easy to clean, monitor for parasites/illness, zero impaction risk. Ideal for new frogs during 30-day quarantine, sick frogs, or emergency budget setups. Can be used long-term if changed daily and enclosure is misted 2-3x daily. Use white, unscented towels—avoid colored/patterned varieties.

Frog Foam (Low-Maintenance Alternative)
Reusable foam pad designed for amphibians. Cushioned surface prevents injury from falls, easy to rinse and reuse weekly. Does NOT retain humidity—requires frequent misting (2-3x daily). Lasts 1-2 years before needing replacement. Popular brands: Frog Foam, Exo Terra Forest Foam.

content.content: AVOID: Sand (impaction risk), gravel (ingestion hazard), reptile carpet (bacteria trap, toes get caught), sphagnum moss (bacteria harboring, impaction risk when ingested), cedar/pine (toxic), soil with fertilizer/perlite.

CRITICAL: When using ANY loose substrate (coco fiber, topsoil mix), you MUST add a leaf litter layer on top. Leaf litter prevents direct substrate contact, provides hiding spots for cleanup crew in bioactive setups, and reduces impaction risk. Use magnolia, oak, or Indian almond leaves.

content.heading: Substrate Depth for White's Tree Frogs

rows: Single solid pad, no layering needed
Shallow for easy cleaning, prevents stagnant pockets
Deeper substrate needed for cleanup crew and plant roots

content.content: Why depth matters: Simple setups stay shallow (1-2") for easy cleaning. Bioactive needs 3-4" for cleanup crew (isopods, springtails) to thrive and plant roots to establish.

content.heading: Moisture Management for White's Tree Frogs

content.text: White's Tree Frogs need DRY substrate, not wet. These are semi-arid frogs—excessive moisture causes bacterial infections and respiratory issues.
Target Moisture Level: Lightly damp to touch, NOT soggy or waterlogged. Substrate should dry out on top layer within 4-6 hours of misting.

items: Mist lightly every 2-3 days (simple setup) or weekly (bioactive)

content.content: Overly Wet Substrate = Bacterial Blooms + Respiratory Infections. If you can squeeze water out of the substrate, it's TOO WET.
